questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus

options.label: B
options.text: Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

options.label: C
options.text: There is a risk of elevation of transaminases

options.label: D
options.text: Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.correct_answer: B. Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 6thleft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:
  • ➤ Double Aortic Arch : This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties. Right Aortic Arch : This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring. Interrupted Aortic Arch : Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus : This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations. Coarctation of the Aorta : It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) : After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery : This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus. Cervical Aortic Arch : Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects : These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk. Vascular Rings : These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.
  • ➤ Double Aortic Arch : This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  • ➤ Double Aortic Arch
  • ➤ Right Aortic Arch : This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  • ➤ Right Aortic Arch
  • ➤ Interrupted Aortic Arch : Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  • ➤ Interrupted Aortic Arch
  • ➤ Persistent Truncus Arteriosus : This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  • ➤ Persistent Truncus Arteriosus
  • ➤ Coarctation of the Aorta : It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  • ➤ Coarctation of the Aorta
  • ➤ Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) : After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  • ➤ Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • ➤ Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery : This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  • ➤ Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery
  • ➤ Cervical Aortic Arch : Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  • ➤ Cervical Aortic Arch
  • ➤ Aortopulmonary Septal Defects : These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  • ➤ Aortopulmonary Septal Defects
  • ➤ Vascular Rings : These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.
  • ➤ Vascular Rings

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? ( AIIMS May 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. Sense changes in muscle tension
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Golgi tendon organ primarily functions to monitor and respond to changes in muscle tension, helping to prevent muscle damage from excessive force during activities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor

options.label: D
options.text: TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.correct_answer: D. TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle is absent in which compartment of the leg? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Posterior superficial compartment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior Superficial Compartment has the gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris muscles. These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. However, this compartment does not have a specific named artery or vein running through it, as the main vessels (the posterior tibial and fibular arteries and their accompanying veins) are located deep in the leg, closer to the bones. Instead, the vascular supply to these muscles comes from branching vessels that penetrate the compartment.
  • ➤ Posterior Superficial Compartment

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.
  • ➤ Subperiosteal Abscess

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? ( INICET May 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland .
  • ➤ Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland .
  • ➤ differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion

options.label: B
options.text: Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

options.label: D
options.text: Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detection of C. Burnetti in a single blood culture is a major criterion for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis due to the organism's strong association with this disease, despite being difficult to culture.

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle

options.label: C
options.text: Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.correct_answer: A. It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs. of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of: ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was found to have splenomegaly, anemia, and jaundice. All of the following are true about this condition mark the wrong one? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Low reticulocyte count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemolytic anemia, there is an increase in reticulocyte count due to compensatory erythropoiesis. This distinguishes it from other anemias where reticulocyte count might be low or normal.

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Test for ANCA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected GPA, the ANCA test is the most useful initial investigation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:
  • ➤ Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.
  • ➤ Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  • ➤ Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  • ➤ Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.

options.label: B
options.text: Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.

options.label: C
options.text: Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

options.label: D
options.text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.correct_answer: C. Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: Lesion of the structure marked '11' causes: ( AIIMS Nov 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The median nerve supplies sensory fibers to the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the radial half of the ring finger. This means that an injury to the median nerve can lead to sensory loss in these areas, including the nail of the index finger.

questions.text: Which of the following systems exhibits a feedback gain of infinity in negative feedback mechanism? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Blood volume control by kidney
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blood volume control by kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood volume control by the kidney exemplifies a highly effective negative feedback mechanism, theoretically approaching infinite gain by maintaining blood volume within a narrow range. While true infinite gain is not possible in biological systems, the kidneys' regulatory function is exceptionally efficient.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is undergoing a renal function test as part of a routine medical check-up. The nephrologist explains that in the first part of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium is reabsorbed along with glucose and amino acids, leading to a higher concentration of chloride in the tubular fluid. In the second half of the PCT, this high chloride concentration facilitates its reabsorption. What is the primary mechanism by which chloride is reabsorbed in the second half of the PCT?

options.label: B
options.text: Passive diffusion due to concentration gradient

questions.correct_answer: B. Passive diffusion due to concentration gradient
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Passive diffusion due to concentration gradient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chloride reabsorption in the second half of the proximal convoluted tubule occurs via passive diffusion due to a concentration gradient created by the prior reabsorption of sodium, glucose, and amino acids.
  • ➤ passive diffusion

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Carcinoma vulva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulvar carcinoma among gynecological malignancies to reduce unnecessary lymph node dissection and its complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete experiences sudden muscle weakness after an intense workout. Upon further investigation, it is found that calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in his skeletal muscle is impaired. The physician explains that this issue may be related to a disruption in the interaction between two key receptors that are involved in calcium release during muscle contraction. Which of the following pairs of receptors is responsible for this interaction in skeletal muscle?

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium receptor and Voltage-gated sodium channel

questions.correct_answer: A. Dihydropyridine receptor and Ryanodine receptor
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dihydropyridine receptor and Ryanodine receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR) mechanically couple with ryanodine receptors (RyR) to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm, which is essential for muscle contraction. This process allows for the rapid response necessary during muscle activation.
  • ➤ dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR)
  • ➤ ryanodine receptors (RyR)

questions.text: Dr. Sanjana is leading a health initiative in Karnataka, focusing on the prevention of anemia among adult women through the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative. She needs to communicate the correct dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation. What is the recommended dose according to the guidelines? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

options.label: B
options.text: 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

options.label: C
options.text: 100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

options.label: D
options.text: 100 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.correct_answer: B. 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in: ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tongue fasciculations are a clinical sign associated with spinal muscular atrophy due to the involvement of lower motor neurons

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: Which mediators involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? (AIIMS MAY 2021) Mast cell Histamine Neutrophils Prostaglandins Leukotrienes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves Mast cells, Histamine, Prostaglandins (D2) and Leukotrienes (C4 and D4).
  • ➤ Early phase
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 377
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 377

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RNA editing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair, which all proceed in the 5' to 3' direction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male farmer from rural area presents to the District hospital with complaints of progressive skin discoloration over his face and arms, which he noticed over the past year. He also reports episodes of dizziness and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic heart conditions and is on multiple medications for his heart rhythm issues. On physical examination, there is a notable bluish-grey discoloration in sun-exposed areas of the skin. His medications include drugs commonly used for arrhythmias, hypertension, and heart rate control. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for his skin discoloration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amiodarone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amiodarone can lead to bluish-grey skin discoloration, particularly in sun-exposed areas, due to its deposition in the skin after prolonged use. This side effect is distinctive to amiodarone among cardiovascular drugs and should be recognized in patients with chronic exposure.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text: All are causes for expanding blind spot, except? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypoplasia of optic disc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Optic disc hypoplasia, a congenital underdevelopment of the optic nerve, does not typically result in an expanding blind spot, unlike conditions like POAG, papilledema, and the presence of medullated nerve fibers, which can directly affect the structure or function of the area surrounding the optic disc.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? ( INICET Nov 2020) Methylmalonyl Co isomerase Homocysteine synthase Folate reductase Methionine synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman from a rural area presents to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of abnormal uterine bleeding and cramping pelvic pain for the past six months. She has no significant past medical history and has never been pregnant. On pelvic examination, the uterus appears normal in size, but the patient is anxious about undergoing any further invasive procedures. An ultrasound is performed, and the physician measures the uterocervical length to assess the uterine anatomy, which will guide further management, including the potential insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD). What is the normal uterocervical length in an adult woman?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6-7 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal uterocervical length in an adult woman is 6-7 cm. Recognizing standard anatomical measurements, including the ovary (3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm) and fallopian tube (10 cm length, 1-2 mm lumen), is essential in guiding gynecological assessments and procedures to ensure accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Creatine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

questions.text: The partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1 st marking is always on the alert line As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation
  • ➤ As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1 st marking is always on the alert line
  • ➤ As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation

questions.text: Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023) 1. Iliococcygeus 2. Pubococcygeus 3. Obturator internus 4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.  1, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chi-square test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following has familial inheritance? ( INICET May 2022) Retinoblastoma Retinitis pigmentosa Муоріа Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: A 18-months-old child is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by his parents with concerns about his growth. The parents report that the child can run and climb stairs but occasionally falls. On examination, the child’s height appears to be around 85 cm. The pediatrician decides to assess the child’s growth in comparison to standard growth charts. The parents are also curious to know at what age their child will attain half of his adult height. What is the typical age range when a child attains half of their adult height?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 18-24 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children typically reach half of their adult height between 18-24 months. Accurate height measurement during this period is crucial for tracking growth and identifying deviations early, allowing for timely intervention when necessary.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pearl index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure. This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods
  • ➤ The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • ➤ This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Factor VII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to which of the following? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind predominantly to albumin in the plasma. This binding affects their pharmacokinetics, distribution, and overall bioavailability.

questions.text: The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

options.label: B
options.text: Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.correct_answer: A. Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality and are crucial for monitoring the impact on health and the environment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia
  • ➤ Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole). While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.
  • ➤ Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • ➤ Fixed drug eruption
  • ➤ While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.
  • ➤ recurrent
  • ➤ same
  • ➤ site
  • ➤ re-exposure
  • ➤ Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12
  • ➤ Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12

questions.text: Choose the right sequence of steps in the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence for the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone involves the enzymes 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, 17 alpha hydroxylase, and 17,20 lyase in that specific order.
